children.text: Goal 1.1: Understand Systems, Order, and Organization
Label the parts of a system.
Explain that a system consists of an organized group of related objects that form a whole.
Compare and contrast different systems.
Analyze different systems.
Define small systems as a part of a whole system.
Determine how small systems contribute to the function of the whole.
Identify the different structural levels of an organism (cells, tissues, organs, and organ systems).
Explain the scientific meaning of system, order, and organization.
Apply the concepts of order and organization to a given system.
Explain the scientific meaning of system, order, and organization.
Apply the concepts of order and organization to a given system.
Explain the scientific meaning of system, order, and organization.
Apply the concepts of order and organization to a given system.
Goal 1.2: Understand Concepts and Processes of Evidence, Models, and Explanations
Make observations and collect data.
Make observations, collect data, and use data.
Make observations, record and interpret data.
Make observations, collect data and evaluate it.
Replicate and/or use models.
Make and record observations then analyze and communicate the collected data.
Define observations and inferences.
Make, describe and/or use models.
Use observations and data as evidence on which to base scientific explanations and predictions.
Explain the difference between observation and inference.
Use models to explain or demonstrate a concept.
Explain how observations and data are used as evidence on which to base scientific explanations and predictions.
Use observations to make inferences.
Use models to explain or demonstrate a concept.
Describe how observations and data are evidence on which to base scientific explanations and predictions.
Use observations to make defendable inferences.
Use models to explain or demonstrate a concept.
Use observations and data as evidence on which to base scientific explanations.
Develop models to explain concepts or systems.
Develop scientific explanations based on knowledge, logic, and analysis.
Use observations and data as evidence on which to base scientific explanations.
Develop models to explain concepts or systems.
Develop scientific explanations based on knowledge, logic, and analysis.
Use observations and data as evidence on which to base scientific explanations.
Develop models to explain concepts or systems.
Develop scientific explanations based on knowledge, logic and analysis.
Goal 1.3: Understand Constancy, Change, and Measurement
Measure in non-standard units.
Measure in both standard and non-standard units.
Measure in standard and non-standard units.
Measure changes that occur.
Measure in both U.S. Customary and International System of Measurement (metric system) units.
Describe how changes occur and can be measured.
Measure in both U.S. Customary and International System of Measurement (metric system) units.
Analyze changes that occur in and among systems.
Measure in both U.S. Customary and International System of Measurement (metric system) units with an emphasis on the metric system.
Analyze changes that occur in and among systems.
Measure in both U.S. Customary and International System of Measurement (metric system) units with an emphasis on the metric system.
Identify concepts of science that have been stable over time.
Recognize changes that occur within systems.
Make metric measurements using appropriate tools.
Measure changes that can occur in and among systems.
Analyze changes that can occur in and among systems.
Measure and calculate using the metric system.
Measure changes that can occur in and among systems.
Analyze changes that can occur in and among systems.
Measure and calculate using the metric system.
Measure changes that can occur in and among systems.
Analyze changes that can occur in and among systems.
Measure and calculate using the metric system.
Goal 1.4: Understand the Theory that Evolution is a Process that Relates to the Gradual Changes in the Universe and of Equilibrium as a Physical State
Apply the concepts of yesterday, today, and tomorrow.
Explain the concepts of past, present, and future.
Apply the concepts of past, present, and future.
Goal 1.5: Understand Concepts of Form and Function
Identify shape and use of objects.
Describe the relationship between shape and use.
Explain the relationship between shape and use.
Explain how the shape or form of an object or system is frequently related to its use or function.
Analyze how the shape or form of an object or system is frequently related to its use and/or function.
Goal 1.6: Understand Scientific Inquiry and Develop Critical Thinking Skills
Make observations.
Make and record observations.
Make observations.
Identify questions to be investigated.
Analyze information and evidence.
Communicate observations.
Identify questions that can be answered by conducting scientific tests.
Conduct scientific tests
Use appropriate tools and techniques to gather and display data.
Use data to construct a reasonable explanation.
Make simple predictions based on data.
Identify logical alternative explanations.
Communicate the results of tests to others.
Write questions that can be answered by conducting scientific tests.
Conduct scientific tests.
Use appropriate tools and techniques to gather and display data.
Use data to construct a reasonable explanation.
Make predictions based on data.
Analyze alternative explanations.
Communicate the results of tests to others in multiple formats.
Write and analyze questions that can be answered by conducting scientific experiments.
Conduct scientific investigations using a control and a variable.
Select and use appropriate tools and techniques to gather and display data.
Use evidence to analyze descriptions, explanations, predictions, and models.
State a hypothesis based on observations.
Compare alternative explanations and predictions.
Communicate scientific procedures and explanations.
Write and analyze questions that can be answered by conducting scientific experiments.
Conduct scientific investigations using a control and variables. Repeat same experiment using alternate variables.
Select and use appropriate tools and techniques to gather and display data.
Use evidence to analyze data in order to develop descriptions, explanations, predictions, and models.
Test a hypothesis based on observations.
Communicate scientific procedures and explanations.
Identify controls and variables used in scientific investigations.
Use appropriate tools and techniques to gather and display data.
Evaluate data in order to form conclusions.
Use evidence and critical thinking to accept or reject a hypothesis.
Evaluate alternative explanations or predictions.
Communicate and defend scientific procedures and explanations.
Identify questions and concepts that guide scientific investigations.
Utilize the components of scientific problem solving to design, conduct, and communicate results of investigations.
Use appropriate technology and mathematics to make investigations.
Formulate scientific explanations and models using logic and evidence.
Analyze alternative explanations and models.
Communicate and defend a scientific argument.
Explain the differences among observations, hypotheses, and theories.
Identify questions and concepts that guide scientific investigations.
Utilize the components of scientific problem solving to design, conduct, and communicate results of investigations.
Use appropriate technology and mathematics to make investigations.
Formulate scientific explanations and models using logic and evidence.
Analyze alternative explanations and models.
Communicate and defend a scientific argument.
Explain the differences among observations, hypotheses, and theories.
Identify questions and concepts that guide scientific investigations.
Utilize the components of scientific problem solving to design, conduct, and communicate results of investigations.
Use appropriate technology and mathematics to make investigations.
Formulate scientific explanations and models using logic and evidence.
Analyze alternative explanations and models.
Communicate and defend a scientific argument.
Explain the differences among observations, hypotheses, and theories.
Goal 1.7: Understand That Interpersonal Relationships Are Important in Scientific Endeavors
Use cooperation and interaction skills.
Demonstrate cooperation and interaction skills.
Practice cooperation and interaction skills.
Goal 1.8: Understand Technical Communication
Follow instructions.
Follow multi-step instructions.
Follow multi-step instructions.
Read and give multi-step instructions.
Analyze and follow multi-step instructions.
Read and follow technical instructions.
Read, give, and execute technical instructions.
Read and evaluate technical instructions.
Analyze technical writing, graphs, charts, and diagrams.
Analyze technical writing, graphs, charts, and diagrams.
Analyze technical writing, graphs, charts, and diagrams.
Goal 2.1: Understand the Structure and Function of Matter and Molecules and Their Interactions
Use senses to describe matter.
Describe properties of objects.
List properties of an object.
Identify the physical properties of solids, liquids, and gases.
Use instruments to measure properties.
Explain that heating and cooling can cause changes of state in common materials.
Describe the physical properties of solids, liquids, and gases.
Use instruments to measure properties
Explain the changes caused by heating and cooling materials.
Describe the differences among elements, compounds, and mixtures.
Compare the physical differences among solids, liquids, and gases.
Explain the nature of physical change and how it relates to physical properties.
Compare and contrast the differences among elements, compounds and mixtures.
Define the properties of matter.
Describe the effect of temperature on density.
Compare densities of equal volumes of a solid, a liquid, or a gas.
Explain the nature of physical change and how it relates to physical properties (the distance between molecules as water changes from ice to liquid water, and to water vapor).
Goal 2.2: Understand Concepts of Motion and Forces
Describe the position and motion of objects. (ex. revolve, rotate, at rest, float, and fall)
Explain how force affects the position and motion of objects.
Describe the effects of different forces (gravity and friction) on the movement, speed, and direction of an object.
Explain motion using Newton's Laws of Motion.
Goal 2.3: Understand the Total Energy in the Universe is Constant
Identify potential and kinetic energy.
Explain that energy can be transformed but cannot be created nor destroyed.
Classify energy as potential and/or kinetic and as energy contained in a field.
Goal 2.4: Understand the Structure of Atoms
Describe the properties, function, and location of protons, neutrons, and electrons.
Explain the processes of fission and fusion.
Describe the characteristics of isotopes.
State the basic electrical properties of matter.
Describe the relationships between magnetism and electricity.
Goal 2.5: Understand Chemical Reactions
Explain how chemical reactions may release or consume energy while the quantity of matter remains constant.
Goal 3.1: Understand the Theory of Biological Evolution
Observe and describe the characteristics of plants and animals.
Describe the life cycle of a plant (seed, growth, reproduction, death).
Describe the life cycle of an animal (birth, development, reproduction, death).
Describe the adaptations of plants and animals to their environment.
Analyze and communicate the adaptations of plants and animals to their environment.
Describe the difference between vertebrate and invertebrate animals.
Classify the five groups of vertebrates (mammal, reptiles, amphibians, birds, and fish) based on characteristics.
Describe how natural selection explains species change over time.
Use the theory of evolution to explain how species change over time.

Explain how evolution is the consequence of interactions among the potential of a species to increase its numbers, genetic variability, a finite supply of resources, and the selection by the environment of those offspring better able to survive and reproduce.
Goal 3.2: Understand the Relationship between Matter and Energy in Living Systems
Describe the difference between living and non-living things.
State that living things need food to survive.
Identify four basic needs of all living things (food, shelter, water, space).
Discuss how animals are suited to live in different habitats.
Describe the energy needed for living systems to survive.
Compare and contrast the energy requirements of plants and animals.
Label a food chain that shows how organisms cooperate and compete in an ecosystem.
Diagram the food web and explain how organisms both cooperate and compete in ecosystems.
Communicate how plants convert energy from the sun through photosynthesis.
Describe how energy stored in food is primarily derived from the sun through photosynthesis.
Describe how the availability of resources (matter and energy) limits the distribution and abundance of organisms.
Illustrate how atoms and molecules cycle among the living and nonliving components of the biosphere.
Identify how energy flows through ecosystems in one direction, from photosynthetic organisms to herbivores, carnivore, and decomposers.
Explain how matter tends toward more disorganized states (entropy).
Explain how organisms use the continuous input of energy and matter to maintain their chemical and physical organization.
Show how the energy for life is primarily derived from the sun through photosynthesis.
Describe cellular respiration and the synthesis of macromolecules.
Show how matter cycles and energy flows through the different levels of organization of living systems (cells, organs, organisms, communities) and their environment.
Goal 3.3: Understand the Cell is the Basis of Form and Function for All Living Things
Compare and contrast the structural differences between plant and animal cells.
Explain the concept that traits are passed from parents to offspring.
Identify the different structural levels of which an organism is comprised (cells, tissues, organs, organ systems, and organisms).
Analyze the structural differences between plant and animal cells.
Describe how traits are passed from parents to offspring.
Explain the relationships among specialized cells, tissues, organs, organ systems, and organisms.
Identify the parts of specialized plant and animal cells.
Identify the functions of cell structures.
Describe cell functions that involve chemical reactions.
Describe how dominant and recessive traits are inherited.
Identify the particular structures that underlie the cellular functions.
Explain cell functions involving chemical reactions.
Explain how cells use DNA to store and use information for cell functions.
Explain how selective expression of genes can produce specialized cells from a single cell.
Goal 4.1: Understand Scientific Theories of Origin and Subsequent Changes in the Universe and Earth Systems
Name the four seasons.
Place the four seasons in order.
Identify the four seasons and their characteristics for a local region.
Describe the characteristics of different weather conditions.
Explain the reasons for length of a day, the seasons, and the year on Earth.
Compare and contrast the basic components of our solar system (planets, sun, moon, asteroids, comets, meteors).
Explain the effect of gravity on orbits and objects.
Explain the effect of moon's gravity on Earth's tides.
Describe the interactions among the solid earth, oceans and atmosphere (erosion, climate, tectonics and continental drift).
Explain the water cycle and its relationship to weather and climate.
Identify cumulus, cirrus, and stratus clouds and how they relate to weather changes.
Explain the interactions among the solid earth, oceans, atmosphere, and organisms.
Identify methods used to estimate geologic time.
Show how interactions among the solid earth, oceans, atmosphere, and organisms have changed the earth system over time.
Explain the current scientific theory that suggests that the solar system formed from a nebular cloud of dust and gas.
Goal 4.2: Understand Geo-chemical Cycles and Energy in the Earth System
Explain the rock cycle and identify the three classifications of rocks.
Explain the internal and external energy sources of the earth

text: Standard 5: Personal and Social Perspectives; Technology

children.text: Goal 5.1: Understand Common Environmental Quality Issues, Both Natural and Human Induced
Describe characteristics of a man-made environment (home, school…).
Identify the characteristics of local natural environments. (playground, backyard).
Compare and contrast man-made and natural environments.
Identify local environmental issues.
Identify issues for environmental studies.
Identify issues for environmental studies.
Analyze environmental issues such as water and air quality, hazardous waste, and depletion of natural resources.
Analyze environmental issues such as water and air quality, hazardous waste, forest health, and agricultural production.
Goal 5.2: Understand the Relationship between Science and Technology
Identify tools people have invented for everyday life and for scientific investigations.
Describe how technology helps develop tools.
Describe the development of tools over time.
Identify tools used for space exploration and for scientific investigations.
Describe how science and technology are part of a student's life.
List examples of science and technology.
Describe how science and technology are part of our society.
Describe how science and technology are interrelated.
Explain how science and technology are interrelated.
Explain how science advances technology.
Explain how science advances technology.
Explain how technology advances science.
Explain how science and technology are pursued for different purposes.
Explain how science advances technology.
Explain how technology advances science.
Explain how science and technology are pursued for different purposes.
Explain how science advances technology.
Explain how technology advances science.
Explain how science and technology are pursued for different purposes.
Goal 5.3: Understand the Importance of Natural Resources and the Need to Manage and Conserve Them
Explain the concept of recycling.
Identify the differences between renewable and nonrenewable resources.
Explain the difference between renewable and nonrenewable resources.
Identify alternative sources of energy.
Describe the difference between renewable and nonrenewable resources.
Describe the difference between renewable and nonrenewable resources.
